title: What a daft daft film
text: Now You See Me 2 is a good lesson on why sloppiness and spontaneity may fail so miserably. It is even more convoluted, even more complicated than its predecessor, and in almost all respects, a failure. Now You See Me 2 lacks the (fairly) witty script of the previous film, instead relying on sagely nebulous claptrap which in reality meant nothing at all. A great chunk of the dialogue felt like a toddler wrote it in alphabeti spaghetti- the script masquerades in being smarter than it really is. The twisting, needlessly complicated storyline is also simply awful. The story felt like it was tacked together with duct tape, disposing of logical inconsistencies in smug grand reveals which in reality only evinces the poor quality of writing. The unexpected twists and surprises of this story are not intellectually satisfying or revelatory- they are merely there to cover up the increasingly deep hole the writers have dug themselves in, burying along any form of coherence or structure in it. The character motivations also felt confused, and the contrived drama typical of aggressively average films are also of course seen here. The only saving grace for this film is in its entertainment value within some scenes, notably a data chip heist scene. The performance of Lizzy Kaplan is also excellent, her character breathing a ray of optimistic sunshine into the dreary, droll male members of the horseman. Overall, Now You See Me 2 is substandard, overly ambitious, and quite a slog. It is a daft daft film.

title: Exciting But Majorly Flawed and Utterly Ridiculous!
text: If David Blaine, David Copperfield and Michael Bay made a film, it would be this.The first film was cool: lots of flashy slight-of-hand, misdirection and stage magic that were slightly plausible in an "Oceans 11" kind of way. This poorly-written sequel is so full of holes and over-the-top illusions it borders on science fiction. The extra backstories just muddy the waters and the unnecessary addition of extra A-listers doesn't add to the story.This films ties up some loose ends that you didn't realize existed from the first film and attempts to leave room for future films.

title: Now You See Me 2 improves with some new tricks, but creates new problems for it's show
text: It's one thing to produce fantasy where wizards can produce magical energy to fight or resurrect the dead with a spell, but something else when your portraying stage magicians. One major rule when making a movie about these illusionists is that no computer-generated imagery can be used what so ever. Part of the reason that translating the stories of magicians to cinema is that the awe of the tricks are from witnessing them live. Adding a camera adds a sense of cynicism that a simple white rabbit out of a top hat could have been done using editing rather then hand trickery. Ironically, much of whatever's added in film to make things more magical suddenly takes away the wonder.The Prestige from Christopher Nolan seems to be the best movie out there about magicians. But when most people think about cinematic illusionists, they think about the 2013 film, Now You See Me. The movie had some interesting ideas, but I found the four horsemen too perfect for their own good. They didn't connect with me, but it did with audiences and was a hit (you have to give the movie credit for being original AND a hit). Now You See Me 2 continues the escapades of the four (in this case five) horsemen.Set a year after the events of the first movie, the horsemen, hypnotist Merritt (played by Woody Harrelson) street magician Atlas (played by Jessie Eisenberg), card handler Jack (played by Dave Franco), and newcomer May (played by Lizzy Caplan) have been in hiding, waiting for their next move from the Eye, the magician society they were recruited into before. With their leader FBI agent Dylan (played by Mark Ruffalo), they are assigned to expose a corrupt businessman whose software can steal data from users. They hijack the launch party, but are interrupted by a unseen individual who reveals that Dylan is in on the four horsemen. The magicians escape, but are unexpectedly taken and brought to Macau. They are brought in front of tech prodigy Walter Mabry (played by Daniel Radcliffe) who used to work with the same business that the horsemen tried to expose. They are given orders to steal the software chip from a secret facility under a casino. The heist goes well, but Mabry turns the tables on them and steels the chip back for his own benefit. Upon finding out that Mabry is the son of Arthur (played by Michael Caine), they travel to London to plan their next act to finally put an end to these villains.I'll say that I liked Now You See Me 2 as much as the last filmwhich was okay. It's not the same thoughts though as while they fixed some problems I had before, but accidentally create new ones. While the four horsemen are still too perfect as heroes, Mark Ruffalo gets some more background and becomes a surprising interesting character to follow. This film continues the heist theme, which seems like a good plan, but a lot of the story gets complicated.A lot of that has to do with the fact the idea of steeling a computer chip has been done hundreds of times before in film, so why should I care about this one? The villains' plans are just as predictable as it's just take over the world. Finally, some of the magic tricks are cool and visually neat (not as much CGI this time), but it requires a major suspension of disbelief. I doubt David Copperfield and Sigfried & Roy could have come up with some of these tricks in just one day. I'll give this five joker card out of ten. If you liked the last movie, you'll probably like this too. It's too much "movie" for me to get into. What I mean by that is I wish I could be seeing these tricks live rather then watch it in a movie. Though there are some tricks, the overall treat just isn't to my taste.

title: Reasonable heist flick at the start. Totally falls apart at the end.
text: Every time someone tries to shoehorn Morgan Freeman into one of these genre knockoffs (Ocean's 11 knockoff in this case; that 'Wanted' one he did with Angelina Jolie was some kind of Da Vinci Code-esque piece of cheese with The Loom of Destiny at the end), the whole thing just goes sideways.This was a perfectly serviceable stylish-if-not-believable heist movie until the last half-hour when the supposed 'reveals' introduce about a million plot holes and 'WTF?s' until you wish it'd just be over already, because it's killing whatever positive feelings you managed to have about it.If you're in the mood for a heist film, go watch Ocean's 11, 12, 13 or 8. title: Five Word Review: Convoluted, Messy Sequelitis; Frequently Fun
text: Unfortunately not titled 'Now You Don't', this sequel to the frothy, enjoyable 2013 sleeper hit adds to its all-star ensemble cast (Lizzy Caplan replaces Isla Fisher and Daniel Radcliffe is introduced as a villain), expands the setting, and ups the stakes, like most sequels. And, like most sequels, it's not as good as the first one. With The Horsemen being threatened by the threat of Daniel Radcliffe (odd to see him in a film about magic eh?) there are more hi-jinks, impossible feats of magic, convoluted twists, and witty repartees between the talented cast. The cast is undoubtedly the strongest thing about this film - the standout scenes are the ones in which The Horsemen are in their element, doing quick flashy magic and impressing everyone. Unfortunately there aren't as many of these scenes as there should be, with the filmmakers seemingly intent on switching from one underdeveloped subplot to another. Mark Ruffalo, as the Head Horseman, spends much of his tins with Morgan Freeman, with the two struggling to sell unconvincing drama. In a bizarre and distracting turn of events, Woody Harrelson takes on a dual role, introducing his character's twin brother as a campy villainous antagonist with almost nothing to add to the story which already has enough characters - it's always good to see more Harrelson but the twin aspect was unnecessary. There's a father-son relationship between Radcliffe and Michael Caine - who is great for his ten minutes of screen time - an FBI investigation team with a young officer who looks up to Ruffalo, a helpful pair of Chinese magicians with some vague link to The Horsemen....it is at times almost as overstuffed as Avengers: Age of Ultron. It's a classic case of sequelitis, and one which dooms the film almost from the get-go. Which is not to say there's not fun to be had: the delectable sleekness of some scenes is sure to bring a smile to the face and with this cast it's impossible not to be entertained. Standouts are Radcliffe's demented bearded tech whizz who is just fantastic to watch. He is an actor who has really thrown off the shackles of the Harry Potter legacy and is now just a great actor to have in anything, now showing his skill as a villain. Lizzy Caplan is bubbly and fun in her role, whilst Jesse Eisenberg, Harrelson, and Dave Franco are all solid as a team - if the widely purported third instalment of this franchise is to go ahead, then a good suggestion would be to bring down the stakes and focus more on the team dynamic. Ultimately, the film is flashy and at times fun, but drags more than its predecessor, is overstuffed, and is simply less enjoyable. One of the main criticisms of the first film was the empty flash, but the sequel has just expanded on that. A decent enough watch, but not something that will be remembered or re-watched. 53/100

title: Seems to have very little purpose or direction
text: The original Now You See Me was not a masterpiece. It had a fun idea and fun characters to go along with it, but it also felt muddled. For example, the whole shadowy organization, The Eye, behind it all felt completely unnecessary. The movie could just have been a fun little heist movie with four magicians deciding to get rich by using their talents. There was absolutely no need to throw in bargain bin Illuminati with rumours of real magic.And of course that bargain bin Illuminati is exactly what they chose to focus on in the sequel. Because of course it was. Gone are the quippy one-liners, gone is the flash and razzle dazzle, gone is the magic. Instead our main characters are on the run. It's all very dark and grim. You can trust no one and the police is right on their tails. Instead of them being two steps ahead of everyone else - you know, the fact that made the previous film so fun to watch - now they're constantly two steps behind. Of course they'll prevail by the end - it's still a movie - but it doesn't feel earned.And let me raise one gripe above others. There's very little magic in this film. Towards the end we start seeing them pull shows once more, and at point it becomes interesting, but before that, almost nothing.Okay, there's one very long scene with card tricks and more specifically card throwing, but that felt so pointlessly unneeded and complicated that it become unintentionally hilarious. If you don't want other people finding the card you're holding, perhaps don't throw it across the room a million times.That being said, the actors were still very enjoyable. Mark Ruffalo gets a lot more screen time this time around and his subplot was the most enjoyable by a wide margin. Perhaps more of that would have fixed the film. Then again, I came to this film to see the Horsemen, so having even less of them could also be very bad.Not a good sequel. Usually these things try to cram too much of what made the previous film work down our throats, but this falls into that other dangerous category: not knowing what made the previous film so good.
